The most common causes of retryable errors are network connection
failures or drops -- it's presumed they may be transient conditions
that will improve in a matter of minutes, hours, or days.

Note that the delay only affects the queue -- essentially host --
on which the retryable error occurred. The time to delay is set
by the Frontier "retry-delay-seconds" setting, and the maximum
number of times an URL will be retriedis set by the "max-retries"
setting.

The delay is currently just a constant interval, though it has
often been suggested to implement an exponentially-increasing delay
in such a situation.

Sometimes these errors don't really have any chance to clear up,
in which case you're just going to fail all "max-retries" times
before moving to the next item in the queue. And, if the next
item in the queue involves a connection against the same host,
which will simply fail again, you're just going to be in a loop
of failures until the queue is exhausted or the operator loses
patience.

So, setting this interval to be smaller could burden target hosts
unfairly. Be careful.

- Gordon @ IA

Kristinn Sigurdsson wrote:
> Queues can be snoozed to enforce politeness (usually just a few 
> seconds), this is controlled by the delay-factor, max-delay-ms 
> and min-delay-ms settings on the Frontier.
>  
> Queues can also be snoozed if a _retryable error_ occurs (i.e. errors 
> that may be caused by transient network issues, such as a server going 
> down etc.) This usually results in snoozing a queue for several minutes 
> 900 seconds (15 min) by default and is controlled by the 
> retry-delay-seconds setting on the Frontier. The number of retries 
> before it gives up is controlled by the max-retries setting.
>  
> Hope this helps.
>  
> - Kris
